attributes.title: Effect of instrumental action-reward contingency on conflict resolution in a Stroop task

q1.value: Effect of instrumental action-reward contingency on conflict resolution

q2.value: Arthur Prével, Ruth Krebs, Senne Braem

q3.value: There is strong evidence that a motivational context, and particularly the presentation of performance-contingent reward, influences cognitive control. Studies have shown that contingent monetary reward improves performance during conflict resolution (Krebs, Boehler, and Woldorff, 2010), task-switching (Braem, 2017), inhibition (Boehler, Schevernels, Hopf, Stoppel, and Krebs, 2014), or proactive control (Chiew and Braver, 2013). However, little is known about how cognitive control is influenced by different types of learned reward contingencies. In this study, instrumental action-reward contingency is manipulated in two color-naming Stroop task experiments. Action-reward contingency is one of the most extensively studied moderator of instrumental learning (e.g., Vaghi, Cardinal, Apergis-Schoute, Fineberg, Sule, & Robbins, 2019), and we aim at testing how cognitive control, and particularly conflict resolution, is influenced by this moderator. The difference between the two experiments consists in the use of cues in the second experiment signaling whether the next word probe stimulus is congruent or incongruent. Thus, the second experiment involves the possibility to prepare for the trial's congruency identity without having seen the target yet. This study is a first step to a systematic investigation of how different motivational contexts influence cognitive control, which is relevant both at a descriptive and a conceptual level of understanding of cognitive control mechanisms. In addition, this would open to more efficient ways to manipulate motivation during cognitive control training, and improve interventions in patients with deficits in cognitive control.

q4.value: Across both experiments, our main hypothesis is that conflict resolution is influenced by instrumental contingency, with improved conflict resolution for positive action-reward contingency in incongruent trials (i.e., incongruent trials are rewarded more), as compared to neutral (i.e., incongruent and congruent trials are rewarded equally) or negative contingencies (i.e., congruent trials are rewarded more). In the first color-naming Stroop task experiment, it is possible that participants detect the action-reward contingencies manipulated but do not change their responses accordingly due to limited time available to adapt attentional settings and prepare a response. Therefore, if instrumental contingency is a moderator of conflict resolution, we believe the effect is potentially more pronounced in the second experiment, in which participants receive a cue that will allow them to prepare for the congruency condition. Therefore, while both experiments first and foremost serve as a test to evaluate our main hypothesis, a secondary hypothesis could be that we expect the effect to be more pronounced in the second versus first experiment.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The study consists of two within-subject experiments. With Types of Trials (congruent, incongruent) and Contingency Blocks (Positive, Neutral, Negative) as within-subject factors.

For the two experiments, the test phase with the three contingency blocks is preceded by a training phase of the color-naming Stroop task. This training consists of a first block during which contingent rewards are not presented, and in a second block during which contingent reward are delivered to correct and fast responses, but independently of the congruency identity of the trial presented. At the end of the reward training block, participants are asked a contingency judgement similar to those asked at the end of each contingency block of the test phase (see the measured variable section). Importantly, for each block of the test phase the participants are not instructed about the manipulated reward contingencies.

q9.value: For both experiment, the order in contingency blocks presentation will be counterbalanced across participants (six permutations). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the six orders, with an equal amount of participants among the different order conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: At this point, the data of 38 participants has been collected but the resulting files have not been opened yet.

question.value: For half of participants, paid and credit students are recruited via the participant database of Ghent University (Sona). For these participants, the study takes place within the Faculty of Psychology at Ghent University. The second half is recruited online via Prolific and tested online. All participants will be aged between 18 and 35 years-old, right-handed, with a normal color perception, normal or corrected-to-normal vision, and no history of diagnosed mental disorders.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 84 in total for the two experiments (42 participants per experiment). This should allow us to test our main hypothesis in each of the two experiments separately. We will attempt to recruit up to 90 participants, assuming that the data of around 5% of participants will show missing or incomplete data, and consequently will be excluded.

q14.value: The target sample size of 90 in total is consistent with the recommendations made by Brysbaert and Stevens (2018), but also with a study we conducted using learned-reward contingencies in a cognitive control task (Prével, Hoofs, and Krebs, in preparation).

question.value:
In Experiments 1 and 2, we manipulate the types of trials as within-subject factor. The two levels of this variable are congruent and incongruent. We also manipulate the contingency between responding correctly during incongruent trials and reward, again as within-subject factor. The three levels of this variable are positive, neutral, and negative. 

In summary, the study consists in two within-subject experiments. With Types of Trials (congruent, incongruent) and Contingency Blocks (Positive, Neutral, Negative) as within-subject factors.

The measured variables are response reaction time and the percentage of errors. In addition, at the end of each block we measure for each contingency manipulated the perceived contingency by asking participants how the presentation of reward is caused by responding correctly during incongruent trials, on a scale between -100 and 100, '-100' being 'did not caused', and '100' being 'absolutely caused'.
Means will be calculated for both RTs and error rates for each combination of congruency condition and reward contingency condition.

For the two experiments, we will use a 2*3 repeated measures ANOVA with Congruency (congruent, incongruent) and Contingency (Positive, Neutral, Negative) as within-subject factors to analyze our results. The main effect of interest will be the interaction between the Congruency and Contingency. If significant, we will evaluate the congruency effects separately for each of the three contingency conditions separately. Our hypothesis is that the congruency effect will be smallest for the positive contingency condition (i.e., where incongruent trials are rewarded most).

q20.value: The effects of aforementioned variables do not require additional transformations.

q21.value: The standard p<.05 will be used for the ANOVA.

q22.value:
For responses reaction times (RTs) analysis, only correct responses slower than 150 ms from probe onset and within +/- 2.5 SDs are considered.

Participants with below-chance accuracy in any of the six contingency by congruency conditions are excluded. 

Data collected from the training phase are not included in the analysis.

q23.value: If a participant shows an empty cell in any of the six contingency by congruency conditions, they will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect the effect to be more pronounced in the second versus first experiment because of the cue manipulation in experiment 2. Thus, we will look for an interaction between the Experiment, the Contingency, and the Congruency. Also, based on the previous study we conducted on the effect of uninstructed learned-reward contingency on cognitive control (Prével, Hoofs, and Krebs, in preparation), and the evidence of differences between early responses in a block and late responses in a block, we will look for relationships between the time in a block and the aforementioned measures. In addition, a linear mixed model might be used to analyze the data because of the repeated measurements used.

q25.value:
Boehler, C. N., Schevernels, H., Hopf, J. M., Stoppel, C. M., & Krebs, R. M. (2014). Reward prospect rapidly speeds up response inhibition via reactive control. Cognitive, Affective, & Behavioral Neuroscience, 14(2), 593-609.

Braem, S. (2017). Conditioning task switching behavior. Cognition, 166, 272-276.

Brysbaert, M., & Stevens, M. (2018). Power analysis and effect size in mixed effects models: A tutorial. Journal of Cognition, 1(1).

Chiew, K. S., & Braver, T. S. (2013). Temporal dynamics of motivation-cognitive control interactions revealed by high-resolution pupillometry. Frontiers in psychology, 4, 15.

Krebs, R. M., Boehler, C. N., & Woldorff, M. G. (2010). The influence of reward associations on conflict processing in the Stroop task. Cognition, 117(3), 341-347.

Vaghi, M. M., Cardinal, R. N., Apergis-Schoute, A. M., Fineberg, N. A., Sule, A., & Robbins, T. W. (2019). Action-outcome knowledge dissociates from behavior in obsessive-compulsive disorder following contingency degradation. Biological Psychiatry: Cognitive Neuroscience and Neuroimaging, 4(2), 200-209.

attributes.title: Associations between chronic alcohol consumption and emotional facial expression processing
attributes.description: This project is a two-part, online study. The first study tests whether chronic alcohol consumption is associated with poorer emotional face recognition. The second study tests whether chronic alcohol consumption is associated with a hostile attribution bias when processing emotional facial expressions, as well as dyadic social interactions. Participants are weekly alcohol consumers over a sustained period for a minimum of 5 years. Weekly units of alcohol consumed are measured to assess chronic alcohol consumption.

attributes.title: The Effects of Physical Distance Cues on Inferences About Intergroup Distinctiveness
attributes.description: Building on the premises of Construal Level Theory of Psychological Distance, in this study we ask whether people would use physical distance cues between two novel social groups to make inferences about the distinctiveness of these groups.

q1.value: The Effects of Physical Distance Cues on Inferences About Intergroup Distinctiveness

q3.value: This research project predicates on Construal Level Theory’s (CLT) premises which suggests that spatial distance cues are linked to the perceived psychological distance (e.g., William and Bargh, 2008), and distance cues result in a representation focusing on higher-order information related to the stimuli (e.g., Idson and Mischel, 2001; Liberman, Sagristano, and Trope, 2002; Stillman, Fujita, Sheldon, and Trope, 2018) . Since people tend to focus on group level information instead of idiosyncratic characteristics of group members when they are depicted as far away from each other (Henderson, 2009), it is possible that observing that there is a large spatial distance between two social groups might lead people to think that these groups are distinct entities, as they will be attending more to the groupness of these social entities, rather than focusing on the individuals which constitute these groups. If they do so, then they are more likely to perceive two novel social groups similar to each other whereas they are more likely to perceive these two groups distinct when they see them placed far afar from each other. And this is the question we ask in this study: we ask whether people would use physical distance cues between two novel social groups to make inferences about the distinctiveness of these groups.

q4.value: People would perceive two minimal social groups (e.g. Group X and Group Y) more similar to each other when there is a small physical distance between the members of the two groups than the cases in which when there is a large physical distance between them.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: This study will have a 2 (number of the group members: single member [i.e. participants will be shown only one member from each group] vs multiple members) x 2 (difference: small [i.e. the physical distance between members of the two group is small] vs large [i.e. the physical distance between members of the two group is large]) between subjects design.

q9.value: Each participant will be assigned to one of the between subjects conditions according to Qualtrics automatic randomization criteria with the only consideration being allocating an equal number of sample size to each cell.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants on Mturk Prime US database will be invited to participate in the study in exchange of one US Dollar for their participation.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 200 participants (N = 50 per cell).

question.value:
DV1: The difference score between these two questions:
“How similar is a Group X member to a typical Group X member?” (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being “very different”, 7 being “very similar”)
and 
“How similar is a Group X member to a typical Group Y member?” (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being “very different”, 7 being “very similar”)

DV2: The difference score between the amount of money allocated to Group X vs Group Y, measured by this question:
“Think about a member of the Group X. This person is responsible for preparing two dinner parties; one for the Group X and one for the Group Y. This person has a 300$ budget in total for both dinners. How much money, do you think, this person would allocate for the dinner of each group?”

1)	The effects of the two independent variables will be tested using two 2(number of the group members: single member vs multiple members) X 2(difference: large vs small) between subjects ANOVAs, one for DV1 and one for DV2. 
2)     If the "number of the group members" variable does not have any effects on either one or both of the DVs according to the ANOVA results, data from the "single member" and the "multiple members" conditions will be combined and the effects of "difference" will be tested using ANOVA(s) for the related DV(s).

q24.value: We expect certain demographic traits and political affiliation of participants may be related to the way that participants attend to the group identification cues. Therefore, we will look for possible relationships between demographic variables (age and gender) and political affiliation and the dependent variables.

q25.value:
Literature Cited:

Henderson, M. D. (2009). Psychological distance and group judgments: The effect of physical distance on beliefs about common goals. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 35(10), 1330-1341. doi: 10.1177/0146167209340905

Idson, L. C., & Mischel, W. (2001). The personality of familiar and significant people: The lay perceiver as a social–cognitive theorist. 
Journal of personality and social psychology, 80(4), 585-596. doi: 10.1037/0022-3514.80.4.585

Liberman, N., Sagristano, M. D., & Trope, Y. (2002). The effect of temporal distance on level of mental construal. Journal of experimental social psychology, 38(6), 523-534. doi: 10.1016/S0022-1031(02)00535-8

Stillman, P. E., Fujita, K., Sheldon, O., & Trope, Y. (2018). From “me” to “we”: The role of construal level in promoting maximized joint outcomes. Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes, 147, 16-25. doi: 10.1016/j.obhdp.2018.05.004

Williams, L. E., & Bargh, J. A. (2008). Keeping one's distance: The influence of spatial distance cues on affect and evaluation. Psychological Science, 19(3), 302-308. doi: 10.1111/j.1467-9280.2008.02084.x

attributes.title: Health inequalities in post-conflict Eastern of the Democratic Republic of Congo: Analysis of current trends and future prospects.

q1.value: Health inequalities in post-conflict Democratic Republic of Congo: Analysis of current trends.

q2.value: Dieudonne Bwirire, Inez Roosen, Rianne Letschert, Nanne (N.K.) de Vries, NTABE, Rik Crutzen

q3.value:
Background

According to the World Health Organization (WHO) Constitution, the enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of health is one of the fundamental rights of every human being [1]. Yet, today, in many countries in the world, large numbers of people do not enjoy this basic right. Part of the explanation for this is that health inequalities still exist between social classes, between different regions, between men and women, and between people from different ethnic backgrounds [2]. Understanding the inequality dynamics at the local level can thus be important and help to better understand overall national inequality [3]. 
We would like to address the following research questions: 
(1) What is the magnitude of health inequality within the post-conflict DRC?
(2) What is the distribution of health inequalities within the post-conflict DRC? 
(3) What are the trends (observed between 2007 & 2013/2014) in health inequality in the post-conflict DRC? 
(4) What factors are associated with structural health inequalities over time and between socio-economic groups within the DRC?

q4.value:
We hypothesize the following for each of the research questions listed above:

Research question 1 (R.Q.1): What is the magnitude of health inequality within the post-conflict DRC?

Populations that have experienced armed conflict often have among the worst indicators of infant, child and maternal mortality, as well as very high levels of psychological impairment, of all countries in the world [4]. In addition, due to a large number of conflicts in different parts of the world, implementing and sustaining health programs have been among the most serious challenges for the health community [5]. 
In the specific case of the post-conflict DRC, there are only a very limited number of studies that could tell us how much health inequalities exists. Thus, we hypothesize that the health inequality has deteriorated within the post-conflict DRC. Analysis of selected child and maternal health indicators will provide an estimate of the magnitude of health inequalities within the post-conflict DRC.

Research question 2 (R.Q.2): What is the distribution of health inequalities within the post-conflict DRC?

Inequalities within a country relate to the distribution of accumulated wealth within a society, and in particular how that society is organized and the social relations and power established among its various strata. It is defined by the history and the political models that have been adopted, and how the state has redistributed national wealth through fiscal and transfer systems, which have generated greater or lesser distributive distances between existing social groups [6]. Without an indication of the distribution of health across the various social subgroups, it can be difficult for the country to claim whether health inequalities increase, decrease, or remain status quo over time. 
The hypothesis regarding the second research question is that there is an unequal distribution of determinants of health at different levels within the DRC, which are associated with higher or lower levels of inequalities in health. More specifically, data on maternal and child care and malnutrition are expected to show that the war has accentuated the health situation, and that the western part of the country will have better outcomes than the eastern part of the country.

Research question 3 (R.Q.3): What are the trends in health inequality in the post-conflict DRC?

In post-conflict situations, there is limited data available for decision-making [7]. Nevertheless, to allow trend analysis, data availability with respect to individuals or groups of interest is essential. With this, it is possible to do much more with the existing data and resources than what is being done currently [9].
The hypothesis regarding the third research question is that between 2007 and 2013/14, the DRC had seen little or no progress towards decreasing health inequalities in the selected maternal and child health indicators. 

Research question 4 (R.Q.4): What could explain structural health inequalities over time and between socio-economic groups within the DRC?. 

People all over the world still live in slums lacking access to basic infrastructure and services such as water, sanitation, electricity, health care and education. Unless decisive actions are taken, there might be 3 billion slum dwellers by 2050 [8]. Therefore, understanding the factors associated with different health inequality determinants increases understanding of what contributes to health inequalities and where targeted programmes could potentially be developed to address them.
Drawing on a large body of reports, the hypothesis regarding the fourth research question proposes that various attributes including type of residence, education level, religion, ethnicity, wealth and occupation influence structural health inequalities between socio-economic groups. Particularly, ethnicity in all its forms plays an important role in health inequalities within the DRC.

In both waves, study population included women in reproductive age (15- 49 years old) and men (age: 15 - 59) who lived in the DRC. q11.value:
Robust data sets rarely exist in these disrupted contexts, therefore innovative methods become even more important for providing the historical lens post conflict or crisis [9]. Our primary data sources are the Democratic Republic of the Congo Demographic and Health Surveys (EDS-RDC) of 2007 and 2013-2014. 
DHS are a basis for many indicators of health that are in turn used to evaluate the effectiveness of programs and interventions and to guide future changes in health programs. They collect information on a number of health, demographic, and social characteristics for nationally representative large samples of women of reproductive age, as well as other variables of interest. We analyse the DRC’s main child and maternal health indicators after the conflict. It is a secondary analysis, in which “data collected by one researcher are re-analysed by another investigator usually to test new research hypotheses” [10].

question.value:
Data collection procedure is identical to the original survey wave (unless noted otherwise).
The EDS-RDC were part of the larger MEASURE DHS project funded by USAID, in which the DRC conducted national household surveys to monitor and evaluate a range of indicators related to population, health and nutrition. Technical assistance in the design, implementation, and analysis of the survey was provided by the global Demographic and Health Surveys project (MEASURE DHS) of Macro International, Inc.
All survey data is presented both nationally and by sub-national reporting area, which are often, but not always, provinces or groups of provinces, and are included in all recoded data files. They were administered by the same company, following a standard set of questionnaires and similar sampling designs.

The Institutional Review Board of Macro International, Inc. reviewed and approved the MEASURE Demographic and Health Surveys Project Phase II. Both, the 2007 and 2013/14 EDS-RDC were categorized under that approval. DHS datasets are available from www.measuredhs.com.

The EDS-RDC I of 2007 (first wave) was the first survey of its kind conducted in the DRC [11]. It was a nationally representative survey designed to provide information on fertility levels and preferences, sexual activity, knowledge and use of family planning, breastfeeding, nutritional status of women and children, mortality of children and adults, maternal mortality, maternal and child health, as well as knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors related to HIV/AIDS and sexually transmitted infections.
The EDS-RDC II (second wave) of 2013-2014 [12] was designed to provide reliable data on fertility and fertility preferences, sexual activity, knowledge and use of family planning, breastfeeding, the nutritional status of women and children under age 5, childhood mortality, adult mortality (including maternal mortality), maternal and child health, HIV/AIDS and STI knowledge, and the use of mosquito nets to prevent malaria.

q13.value:
The DHS are cross-sectional and nationally representative surveys in low- and middle-income countries. They adopt a multi-stage cluster design and samples selected for enumeration are ensured to be representative and comparative across countries. They  involved a two-stage cluster and systematic sampling design with households selected at random. Respondents were selected on the basis of being female (for the female survey) or male (for the male survey) and whether the respondent was a usual member of the household or having spent the night prior to the survey in the household. 
During the EDS-RDC I of 2007, a total of 8.886 households were randomly selected, the final sample included women of age from 15 to 49 (n= 9.995) and men of age from 15 to 59 (n= 4.757). The total sample size was 14.752. While during the EDS-RDC II of 2013/14, a total of 18.171 households were randomly selected, the sample included women of age from 15 to 49 (n= 18.827) and men of age from 15 to 59 (n= 8.656). The total sample size was 27.483.
 
These surveys employed standard Demographic Health Surveys (DHS) questionnaires and techniques for data collection. The women’s Questionnaire was used to collect respondent’s individual characteristics including age, marital status, occupation, residence as well as other information on topics including; reproductive history; contraceptive knowledge and use; antenatal, delivery and postnatal care; marriage; attitudes about family planning.

q14.value:
DHS surveys are designed to provide reliable estimates for most of the key DHS indicators at the national level and as well as at the country’s first administrative level (region/province). At the first stage, the national territory was divided into sample domains corresponding to the DRC’s provinces. 
For urban areas, neighborhoods of cities and towns were sampled, whereas in rural areas, villages and chiefdoms were sampled. The final sampling unit selected was the cluster (neighborhood or village) and, clusters were randomly selected as primary sampling units. Subsequently, a fixed number of households were chosen from each of the selected clusters based on the probability proportional to size technique. 
DHS follows standard sampling procedure and detailed information can be obtained from the Measure DHS webpage.

question.value: This is not applicable.

Given the limited data availability in post-conflict situations, it appears that health status and mortality are the most useful indicators since they are based on data availability. 
For in-depth analysis, we will use the following: 
•Child health indicators: Child mortality, Child nutrition, Breastfeeding, Immunization, Prevalence and treatment of Acute Respiratory Infections (ARI), fever (related to ARI not Malaria), and diarrhea. 
•Maternal health indicators: Prenatal care, Delivery care, Postnatal care, Access to health and Maternal mortality. 
Furthermore, variables considered as predictors of structural health inequality including type or place of residence, highest education level, religion, ethnicity, wealth index and respondent current working situation will be used.

To ascertain prevailing levels of inequality and changes over time there is a need to have an effective means of displaying distributions and of comparing them to one another – ideally through a summary index. In this study, data from Demographic and Health Surveys of 2007, 2013/14 will be analysed for inequities in health using different concentration curves/indices: 

(1)The standard Concentration Index (CI): it is the most appropriate measure of health inequality, since it meets the three basic requirements of a health inequality index, namely, ‘… (i) that it reflects the socio-economic dimension to inequalities in health; (ii) that it reflects the experiences of the entire population; and (iii) that it is sensitive to changes in the distribution of the population across socioeconomic groups …’ [13].
The concentration index is defined as twice the area between the concentration curve and the line of equality. The value of the concentration index can vary between –1 and +1. Its negative values imply that a variable is concentrated among disadvantaged people while the opposite is true for its positive values. When there is no equality, the concentration index will be zero. While the original application of CI was to study income inequality [14], economists have since extended the application of CI to study social inequality in health [13, 15, 16].

(2)The Wealth Index: is based on a set of household characteristics and asset ownership and was explicitly designed to overcome acknowledged challenges in measuring income [17]. Given that there is no single household characteristic or asset that gives us enough information to determine whether someone is poor or not, one way of looking at relative poverty is to divide the population into equal quintiles (which is a fifth (20%) of the population). Wealth quintiles are commonly used as proxies of socioeconomic position, especially in low income countries where lack of data is customary. They are measured in a standardized way in each DHS by an asset index which is constructed from household asset data and dwelling characteristics. Based on the asset index, the population is divided into five wealth quintiles. However, it can be difficult to summarize household wealth represented by each of the assets and household characteristics, therefore Principal Components Analysis (PCA) has been suggested as a solution. In this study, we will use PCA which is a statistical method which determines the relative importance of each variable when seeking to summarize a set of variables [18]. 

(3) Z-score: will be used as descriptor of child nutrition. Both wasting (a sign of acute malnutrition)  and stunting (a sign of chronic malnutrition) will be measured.

Data analysis

To correctly answer our four key research questions, we will proceed as follows:

First, in order to document the magnitude of health inequities, data are required on: (i) a measure of health; and (ii) a measure of social position or an “equity stratifier” that defines strata in a social hierarchy. We will assess the changes in the magnitude of health inequalities across different time periods using the ranges, including rate ratios (RR) and rate differences (RD). These measures compare the range in rates of illness/mortality between the least healthy and the healthiest groups or between the lowest and the highest socioeconomic groups. In this regard, we will measure the ranges respectively, for the indicators: child mortality, child nutrition, maternal mortality, Immunization, breastfeeding, fever, diarrhea, prevalence and treatment of Acute Respiratory Infections (ARI).

Second, we will analyze geographic and wealth inequalities in health distribution using concentration indices (CIs) and curves. The CI takes values between – 1 (when all the population’s health is concentrated in the hands of the most disadvantaged person) and + 1 (when all the population’s health is concentrated in the hands of the least disadvantaged person). If health is equally distributed across socioeconomic groups, the concentration curve will coincide with the diagonal. We will calculate concentration indices (CIs) for the indicators: prenatal care, postnatal care, C-section and delivery of care.

Third, we will assess trends in health inequities by comparing the concentration indices of maternal and child health services utilization variables between the 2007 and 2013/14 waves using Wagstaff two groups concentration indices comparison method. The concentration curve plots the cumulative percentage of the health variable against the cumulative percentage of the sample, ranked by their socioeconomic status, beginning with the most disadvantaged, and ending with the least disadvantaged. Similarly, we will use the concentration indices to measure the trends in health services utilization (access to health) for maternal and child health care services.

Fourth, we will decompose health inequalities into its contributing factors using a decomposition analysis (multivariate analysis). This method of analysis allows one to estimate how determinants proportionally contribute to inequality in a health variable. It will enable us to quantify the real contribution of each determinant of a health variable - controlled for the other determinants - to socioeconomic inequality in that health variable. 
Following dependent variables (child and maternal health indicators) and independent variables (survey period (2007 versus 2013/14), region (Eastern part of the DRC, Western part of the DRC and the capital city of the DRC) will be used. Additional control variables such as wealth, education, employment status, place of residence (urban vs rural) and ethnicity will be used.

Data management and data analysis will be performed by using STATA Version 11 (STATA Corp., College Station, TX, USA) and Distributive Analysis/Analyse Distributive (DAD) 4.4 [19].

q20.value: In this study, a concentration index cannot be computed directly from such categorical data. However, to facilitate comparisons across the two surveys (waves), we are planning to recode data files.

q21.value: For all selected indicators, confidence intervals will be calculated. Effects of increasing health inequalities will be reported with 95% confidence intervals (CI). Inferences will be made based on the p-value (p < .05) concerning the t-statistic regarding health inequalities.

q23.value: We will not perform an additional imputation, meaning we will not add estimate values to replace the missing values. However, for each outcome variable separately we will check if respondents are missing. We will delete the missing respondents in the specific analysis of the related dependent variable. Therefore, it is possible that one  respondent can be included for one analysis if he/she did answer the question to that outcome variable and deleted in another analysis if he/she did not answer the question to that variable.

Background

According to the World Health Organization (WHO) Constitution, the enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of health is one of the fundamental rights of every human being [1]. Yet, today, in many countries in the world, large numbers of people do not enjoy this basic right. Part of the explanation for this is that health inequalities still exist between social classes, between different regions, between men and women, and between people from different ethnic backgrounds [2]. Understanding the inequality dynamics at the local level can thus be important and help to better understand overall national inequality [3]. 
We would like to address the following research questions: 
(1) What is the magnitude of health inequality within the post-conflict DRC?
(2) What is the distribution of health inequalities within the post-conflict DRC? 
(3) What are the trends (observed between 2007 & 2013/2014) in health inequality in the post-conflict DRC? 
(4) What factors are associated with structural health inequalities over time and between socio-economic groups within the DRC?

registration_responses.q16.question: This is not applicable.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Given the limited data availability in post-conflict situations, it appears that health status and mortality are the most useful indicators since they are based on data availability. 
For in-depth analysis, we will use the following: 
•Child health indicators: Child mortality, Child nutrition, Breastfeeding, Immunization, Prevalence and treatment of Acute Respiratory Infections (ARI), fever (related to ARI not Malaria), and diarrhea. 
•Maternal health indicators: Prenatal care, Delivery care, Postnatal care, Access to health and Maternal mortality. 
Furthermore, variables considered as predictors of structural health inequality including type or place of residence, highest education level, religion, ethnicity, wealth index and respondent current working situation will be used.
registration_responses.q18.question:
To ascertain prevailing levels of inequality and changes over time there is a need to have an effective means of displaying distributions and of comparing them to one another – ideally through a summary index. In this study, data from Demographic and Health Surveys of 2007, 2013/14 will be analysed for inequities in health using different concentration curves/indices: 

(1)The standard Concentration Index (CI): it is the most appropriate measure of health inequality, since it meets the three basic requirements of a health inequality index, namely, ‘… (i) that it reflects the socio-economic dimension to inequalities in health; (ii) that it reflects the experiences of the entire population; and (iii) that it is sensitive to changes in the distribution of the population across socioeconomic groups …’ [13].
The concentration index is defined as twice the area between the concentration curve and the line of equality. The value of the concentration index can vary between –1 and +1. Its negative values imply that a variable is concentrated among disadvantaged people while the opposite is true for its positive values. When there is no equality, the concentration index will be zero. While the original application of CI was to study income inequality [14], economists have since extended the application of CI to study social inequality in health [13, 15, 16].

(2)The Wealth Index: is based on a set of household characteristics and asset ownership and was explicitly designed to overcome acknowledged challenges in measuring income [17]. Given that there is no single household characteristic or asset that gives us enough information to determine whether someone is poor or not, one way of looking at relative poverty is to divide the population into equal quintiles (which is a fifth (20%) of the population). Wealth quintiles are commonly used as proxies of socioeconomic position, especially in low income countries where lack of data is customary. They are measured in a standardized way in each DHS by an asset index which is constructed from household asset data and dwelling characteristics. Based on the asset index, the population is divided into five wealth quintiles. However, it can be difficult to summarize household wealth represented by each of the assets and household characteristics, therefore Principal Components Analysis (PCA) has been suggested as a solution. In this study, we will use PCA which is a statistical method which determines the relative importance of each variable when seeking to summarize a set of variables [18]. 

(3) Z-score: will be used as descriptor of child nutrition. Both wasting (a sign of acute malnutrition)  and stunting (a sign of chronic malnutrition) will be measured.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Data analysis

To correctly answer our four key research questions, we will proceed as follows:

First, in order to document the magnitude of health inequities, data are required on: (i) a measure of health; and (ii) a measure of social position or an “equity stratifier” that defines strata in a social hierarchy. We will assess the changes in the magnitude of health inequalities across different time periods using the ranges, including rate ratios (RR) and rate differences (RD). These measures compare the range in rates of illness/mortality between the least healthy and the healthiest groups or between the lowest and the highest socioeconomic groups. In this regard, we will measure the ranges respectively, for the indicators: child mortality, child nutrition, maternal mortality, Immunization, breastfeeding, fever, diarrhea, prevalence and treatment of Acute Respiratory Infections (ARI).

Second, we will analyze geographic and wealth inequalities in health distribution using concentration indices (CIs) and curves. The CI takes values between – 1 (when all the population’s health is concentrated in the hands of the most disadvantaged person) and + 1 (when all the population’s health is concentrated in the hands of the least disadvantaged person). If health is equally distributed across socioeconomic groups, the concentration curve will coincide with the diagonal. We will calculate concentration indices (CIs) for the indicators: prenatal care, postnatal care, C-section and delivery of care.

Third, we will assess trends in health inequities by comparing the concentration indices of maternal and child health services utilization variables between the 2007 and 2013/14 waves using Wagstaff two groups concentration indices comparison method. The concentration curve plots the cumulative percentage of the health variable against the cumulative percentage of the sample, ranked by their socioeconomic status, beginning with the most disadvantaged, and ending with the least disadvantaged. Similarly, we will use the concentration indices to measure the trends in health services utilization (access to health) for maternal and child health care services.

Fourth, we will decompose health inequalities into its contributing factors using a decomposition analysis (multivariate analysis). This method of analysis allows one to estimate how determinants proportionally contribute to inequality in a health variable. It will enable us to quantify the real contribution of each determinant of a health variable - controlled for the other determinants - to socioeconomic inequality in that health variable. 
Following dependent variables (child and maternal health indicators) and independent variables (survey period (2007 versus 2013/14), region (Eastern part of the DRC, Western part of the DRC and the capital city of the DRC) will be used. Additional control variables such as wealth, education, employment status, place of residence (urban vs rural) and ethnicity will be used.

Data management and data analysis will be performed by using STATA Version 11 (STATA Corp., College Station, TX, USA) and Distributive Analysis/Analyse Distributive (DAD) 4.4 [19].

q1.value: Dark Triad Personalites and Intuitions about Anti-Natalist Cases

q3.value: Anti-natalism is the view that procreation is bad because it is a harm to those brought into existence. To this point, no empirical investigation into the relationship between anti-natalist views and personality or mood has been done. This study attempts to close this gap in the literature by providing such evidence. First, the relationship between dark triad personalities, i.e. Machiavellianism, narcissism, and psychopathy, and anti-natalist intuitions is examined. Second, the role of subclinical depression on those anti-natalist intuitions is also investigated. Most broadly, this research attempts to clarify the relationship between depressive mood and psychopathic personality traits and anti-natalism.

q4.value:
If dark triad personalities are associated with anti-natalist intuitions, then one expects statistically significant correlations between anti-natalist intuitions and dark triad personality types (especially Machiavellianism and psychopathy). These correlations would be positive.

If depressive are associated with anti-natalist intuitions, then one expects statistically significant correlations between anti-natalist intuitions and depression scale measures. The correlations would be positive.

attributes.title: Self- and Other-Compassion Induction
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value: The IV is the Group which has 2 levels: self-compassion condition and other-compassion condition. It is a between group design. Participants will be assigned randomly to their condition; it will be counterbalanced by gender and student vs. general population.

question2b.value: The dependent variables are the change scores (pre – post induction) of the state self-compassion scale, the state general other-compassion scale, the state specific other-compassion scale, and the affect scale.

question3b.value: There will be six covariates: the narcissistic personality inventory score, the regulatory focus questionnaire score, the hypersensitive narcissism scale score, the Levenson self-report psychopathy score, the trait self-compassion scale score, and the trait compassion scale score.

question10b.value:
Participants will be recruited at XXX University and online and will be invited to individual 1 ½ hour time-slots. Before the participants’ arrival, the present researcher will assess the stratification lists to determine which condition the participants would be in. Four lists will be used to stratify and ensure an even distribution of male/student, male/general-population, female/student, and female/general population in each induction condition. 
Upon arrival, participants will be briefed and give written consent. Next, participants will be presented with a laptop with the first block of questionnaires. This includes the demographical data and the trait measures. After, participants will be introduced by the researcher to the induction task, depending on the condition the participants were placed in, the instruction will either follow the SCMI or the OCMI. At this point, the participants will choose their specific situation. Following, participants will continue to fill out the manipulation check and the pre-induction state measures. After, participants will follow the induction by writing about 1. Mindfulness; 2. Common humanity; and 3. (Self-)kindness as specified through written instructions on the laptop. Once the participants finish writing, they will be asked to read what they have written carefully before answering the attention check. Next, the manipulation check item will be shown again, followed by the post-induction state measures. Once the participants finish the measures, they will be asked to write about what they think the study was about and how they felt during participation. Lastly, they will be debriefed and thanked for their participation. Participants will receive a compensation of either University participation credits or a voucher worth €12.50. 



Order Other-Compassion Condition: 
1.	Demographics: age, sex, nationality, education, marital status, employment, and medication. 
Trait measures:
2.	Trait Self-Compassion: Trait self-compassion was measured using the 12-item short form Self-Compassion Scale (SCS-SF; Raes et al., 2011). Items are rated on a 5-point Likert-scale. The scale includes three positive (self-kindness, common humanity, and mindfulness) and three negative components (self-judgement, isolation, and over-identification) of self-compassion.
3.	Trait Other-Compassion: The 16-item Compassion Scale (Pommier, Neff, & Toth-Kiraly, 2019) was used to measure trait other-compassion. Each item is rated on a 5 point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (almost never) to 5 (almost always). The scale includes three positive (kindness, common humanity, and mindfulness) and three negative components (indifference, separation, and disengagement) of compassion with factor loadings of .50 or higher.
4.	Regulatory Focus: Chronic regulatory focus will be measured by the 11-item Regulatory Focus Questionnaire (RFQ; Higgins et al., 2001), which aims to assess participants’ subjective prevention/promotion successes and failures. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (never/certainly false) to 5 (very often/certainly true). 
5.	Grandiose Narcissism: The 37-item Narcissistic Personality Inventory (NPI; Raskin & Hall, 1979; Morf & Rhodewalt, 1993) measures grandiose narcissistic traits. The NPI approaches narcissism dimensionally and only includes factor loadings greater than .35 (Emmons, 1987; Brown & Zeigler-Hill, 2004). Its items are scored on a 7-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (strongly agree) to 7 (strongly disagree). It has a four-factor loading solution: Leadership – Authority, Self-Absorption – Self-Administration, Superiority – Arrogance, and Exploitiveness – Entitlement (Emmons, 1987). 
6.	Vulnerable Narcissism: The 10-item Hypersensitive Narcissism Scale (HSNS; Hendin & Cheek, 1997) measures vulnerable narcissistic traits. Items are rated on a 7-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). 
7.	Psychopathy: The 26-item Levenson Self-Report Psychopathy Scale (LSRP; Levenson, Kiehl, & Fitzpatrick, 1995) measures the dimensions of sub-clinical psychopathic traits. The scale has an optimal 2-factor structure (Lynam, Whiteside, & Jones, 1999; Douma et al., in press); one primary psychopathy subscale measuring selfish, uncaring, and manipulative content towards others, and one secondary psychopathy subscale assessing anti-social behavior, impulsivity, and a self-defeating lifestyle. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). 

Pre-Induction State measures:
8.	State Self-Compassion: To measure state self-compassion, the newly developed state Self-Compassion Scale (Neff, in press) will be used, in which participants are asked to think of a painful or difficult situation in their life while answering the items. The scale consists of 18 items which are scored on a 5 point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (not at all true for me) to 5 (very true for me). The measure includes 6 subscales: kindness, self-judgement, common humanity, isolation, mindfulness, and over-identification. 
9.	Affect: An adapted version of the Affect Valuation Index (AVI; Tsai & Knutson, 2006) will be used to measure changes in positive and negative affect. The original AVI asks responders to indicate their average ideal and actual affect over the past week, whereas this study asked to rate the current actual affect. 30-items were rated on a 5-point Scale ranging from 1 (never) to 5 (all the time). 
10.	State Other-Compassion (General): The General State Other-compassion scale was developed by the current authors by adapting the items on the Compassion Scale to match the language used in the state Self-Compassion Scale. The instructions of the questionnaire ask participants to indicate how they feel about people in general (everyoneone, strangers neighbours etc…) right now. The final version includes 16-items, which are scored on a 5-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very true for me). The items are grouped into six subscales, following the Compassion scale: kindness, common humanity, mindfulness, indifference, separation, and disengagement).
11.	Specific Person Check: Participants are asked to pick a specific person they think about during the induction. The are supposed to name the person, indicate their relationship, how important that person is to them and how much they like that person. 
12.	Manipulation Check: Before and after the induction a manipulation check will be inserted, in which participants indicate how compassionate they feel for their chosen person in the moment. Answers are scored on a 5-point Likert-Scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (a great deal). 
13.	State Other-Compassion (Specific): The State Specific Other-compassion scale was developed by the current authors by adapting the items on the Compassion Scale to match the language used in the state Self-Compassion Scale, while consulting with Neff who’s developed previous compassion scales with her team. The instructions of the questionnaire ask participants to think about a difficult or painful situation someone they know is experiencing and indicate how they feel about the specific person right now. The final version includes 16-items, which are scored on a 5-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very true for me). The items are grouped into six subscales, following the Compassion scale: kindness, common humanity, mindfulness, indifference, separation, and disengagement).
14.	Other-Compassion Induction: Participants will be asked to think of a particular situation that is painful or difficult to someone they know before the induction.
Other-compassion will be induced by administering an Other-Compassion Mindstate induction, which was developed by the current authors by adapting Neff et al.’s SCMI. The current authors have changed the wording to facilitate other-compassion by asking the participants to think of a particular situation that is painful or difficult to someone they know, while encouraging the participant to relate to the other person’s struggle. The induction follows the three positive components of compassion: mindfulness, common humanity, and kindness. Each component is facilitated by a component specific writing prompt, which asks participants to write at least 200 words of compassionate language to their chosen person. The writing task is followed by an attention check which asks participants to indicate what was asked of them during the writing ask, i.e. to write about someone’s feelings in an accepting and validating way, consider how going through difficult situations is part of being human, and write to the other person like a supportive friend. Apart from the correct above option, two more items are included in the attention check which do not fit describe the task accurately.
Post-Induction State measures:
15.	Manipulation Check (see above) 
16.	State Other-Compassion (Specific) (see above)
17.	State Other-Compassion (General) (see above)
18.	State Self-Compassion (see above)
19.	Affect (see above)
20.	 Overall manipulation check (what was the study about? How did you feel while participating?)


Order Self-Compassion Condition: 
1.	Demographics 
Trait measures:
2.	Trait Self-Compassion
3.	Trait Other-Compassion
4.	Regulatory Focus 
5.	Grandiose Narcissism 
6.	Vulnerable Narcissism 
7.	Psychopathy 

Pre-Induction State measures:
8.	State Other-Compassion (General)
9.	Specific Person Check
10.	State Other-Compassion (Specific)
11.	Affect 
12.	Manipulation Check: Before and after the induction a manipulation check will be inserted, in which participants indicate how bad they feel about their chosen situation in the moment. Answers are given on a 5-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (extremely bad) to 5 (extremely good).
13.	State Self-Compassion 
14.	Self-Compassion Induction: Participants will be asked to think of a particular situation that is painful or difficult to them before the induction.
Self-compassion will be induced by administering the Self-Compassion Mindset Induction (SCMI; Neff et al., in preparation). The SCMI experimentally induces a self-compassionate mindset, in which participants are asked to think of one specific situation that is currently painful or difficult for them. The induction follows the three positive components of self-compassion: mindfulness, common humanity, and kindness. Each component has its own writing prompt which encourages participants to write at least 200 words addressed to themselves in a compassionate language. The writing task will be followed by an attention check in which participants indicate what was asked of them during the induction, i.e. to write about their feelings in an accepting and validating way, consider how going through difficult situations is part of being human, and write to themselves like a supportive friend. The intention check includes the above option, in addition to two other items, which do not accurately describe what was asked of them. 
Post-Induction State measures:
15.	Manipulation Check (see above)
16.	State Self-Compassion 
17.	Affect 
18.	State Other-Compassion (General) 
19.	State Other-Compassion (Specific) 
20.	Overall manipulation check

question4b.value: Other than good English or Dutch language abilities, there are no pre-selection rules.

question5b.value: Participants will be recruited through the University’s research participation system, flyer advertisement, and online/social media advertisement through e.g. Facebook. Data will be collected from participants who give written consent, are above 18 years of age, and have good Dutch or English language abilities. The participation will take place within the university buildings of XXX University.

question6b.value:
Research which has previously measured self-compassion before and after a compassion induction (though a different induction technique was used, i.e. compassion focused therapy) has shown an effect size of d = .57 (Sommers-Spijkerman et al. (2018)) when assessing 120 participants (60 per group). This leads us to assume that we can also expect a medium effect size. 
Based on a g*power calculation for ANCOVA with an effect size of f = .25 (medium), power = .80, and alpha = .05 with 1 IV with 2 levels and 6 covariates, we require a sample size of at least n = 158 participants. Currently we are aiming to collect 200 participants, 100 per group.

question7b.value: Data collection will be terminated once the data of 200 participants has been collected.

question8b.value:
Cases will be excluded if the induction wasn’t completed or participants decide to withdraw prematurely. Cases may be excluded if the manipulation checks have been failed, i.e. not having understood the instruction of the induction. 
Data will be excluded on a data-based outlier criterion of values below or above 2 standard deviations.

question1a.value:
Hypothesis 1: Both self- and other-compassion inductions will impact both self- and other-compassion (specific and general) outcomes, but this effect will be largest in the specific experimental factor (i.e. the self-compassion induction will primarily lead to an increase in self-compassion, and the other-compassion induction will primarily lead to an increase in other-compassion). 

Hypothesis 2: Regulatory focus is expected to be a negative covariate, thus, the higher the avoidant focus is, the lower the overall increase in both conditions on both self-compassion and other-compassion will be. 

Hypothesis 3: Narcissistic and psychopathic traits will act as covariates, in which (a) in the self-compassion condition higher scores in narcissism and psychopathy will lead to a stronger increase in self-compassion, but a less strong increase in other-compassion and (b) in the other-compassion condition higher narcissism or psychopathy scores will lead to a weaker increase in other-compassion but a stronger increase in self-compassion, (c) narcissistic and psychopathic traits will increase specific other-compassion more than general other-compassion 

Hypothesis 4: the effects for H3 will be most prominent in grandiose compared to vulnerable narcissism. 

Hypothesis 5: Trait self-compassion and trait other-compassion will have a positive influence on the effectiveness of both inductions. Trait self-compassion will have a greater influence on the self-compassion induction than the other-compassion induction, and trait other-compassion will have a greater influence on the other-compassion induction than the self-compassion induction. 

Hypothesis 6: Narcissistic and psychopathic traits will have a stronger positive effect on specific other-compassion than general-other compassion. This effect will be less strong for vulnerable narcissistic traits than for grandiose narcissistic traits. 

Hypothesis 7: Both the self- and other-compassion induction will increase positive affect. Self-compassion will show a larger increase in affect than other-compassion induction.

question3a.value:
In the self-compassion condition, participants will be asked to indicate how bad they feel about their chosen situation before and after the induction, the manipulation was successful if they feel better or at least the same about their situation, but not worse. 

In the other-compassion condition, participants will be asked to indicate how compassionate they feel for their specific person. The manipulation was successful if they feel the same or better about that person. 

Lastly, at the end of the study all participants will be asked to write down what they think the study was about and how they felt while participating. The manipulation was successful if the participants weren’t able to guess the true aim of the study.

question1c.value: Group. state self-compassion change score (pre self-compassion - post self-compassion), state other-compassion general (pre - post), state other-compassion specific (pre-post), affect (pre-post).

question3c.value: To analyse the differences between the two condition groups (self-compassion induction vs. other-compassion induction) on the dependent variables a MANOVA will be conducted. The group variable will be the fixed factor, and the change in state self-compassion, state general other-compassion, state specific other-compassion,  and affect will be the dependent variables. (Hypothesis 1 + 7)

question1c.value: Change scores in state self-compassion (pre-post), state general othger-compassion (pre-post), state specific other-compassion (pre-post), and affect (pre-post). Further, the total NPI score, total HSNS, and total LSRP. Subscale scores for NPI and LSRP may be used for more detailed analyses. (Hypothesis 3 + 4 + 6)

question3c.value:
4 ANCOVAS with either change in state self-compassion, or state general other-compassion, or state specific other compassion, or affect as the dependent variable, group as the fixed factor, and NPI as a covariate 
4 ANCOVAS with either change in state self-compassion, or state general other-compassion, or state specific other compassion, or affect as the dependent variable, group as the fixed factor, and HSNS as a covariate 
4 ANCOVAS with either change in state self-compassion, or state general other-compassion, or state specific other compassion, or affect as the dependent variable, group as the fixed factor, and LSRP as a covariate

question4c.value:
The NPI and HSNS are used as narcissism has had mixed findings in previous research. It can be assumed that is is negatively related to low other-compassion, through superiority and low concerns for others and to high self-compassion as it may relate to self-confidence and authority feelings typical in narcissism. 
The LSRP (psychopathy) is added as psychopathy does not seem to have been measured with compassion, but rather only with empathy, and findings have been mixed. Theoretically, it would be logical that psychopathy has an influence on compassion due to characteristics such as coldheartedness.

question1c.value: Change scores in state self-compassion (pre-post), state general othger-compassion (pre-post), state specific other-compassion (pre-post), and affect (pre-post). Further, the trait self-compassion and trait other-compassion scores calculated as intended by the authors of the scale and possible sub scale calculation (positive and negative scales). (Hypothesis 5)
