registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
Hypothesis 1: Both self- and other-compassion inductions will impact both self- and other-compassion (specific and general) outcomes, but this effect will be largest in the specific experimental factor (i.e. the self-compassion induction will primarily lead to an increase in self-compassion, and the other-compassion induction will primarily lead to an increase in other-compassion). 

Hypothesis 2: Regulatory focus is expected to be a negative covariate, thus, the higher the avoidant focus is, the lower the overall increase in both conditions on both self-compassion and other-compassion will be. 

Hypothesis 3: Narcissistic and psychopathic traits will act as covariates, in which (a) in the self-compassion condition higher scores in narcissism and psychopathy will lead to a stronger increase in self-compassion, but a less strong increase in other-compassion and (b) in the other-compassion condition higher narcissism or psychopathy scores will lead to a weaker increase in other-compassion but a stronger increase in self-compassion, (c) narcissistic and psychopathic traits will increase specific other-compassion more than general other-compassion 

Hypothesis 4: the effects for H3 will be most prominent in grandiose compared to vulnerable narcissism. 

Hypothesis 5: Trait self-compassion and trait other-compassion will have a positive influence on the effectiveness of both inductions. Trait self-compassion will have a greater influence on the self-compassion induction than the other-compassion induction, and trait other-compassion will have a greater influence on the other-compassion induction than the self-compassion induction. 

Hypothesis 6: Narcissistic and psychopathic traits will have a stronger positive effect on specific other-compassion than general-other compassion. This effect will be less strong for vulnerable narcissistic traits than for grandiose narcissistic traits. 

Hypothesis 7: Both the self- and other-compassion induction will increase positive affect. Self-compassion will show a larger increase in affect than other-compassion induction.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a:
In the self-compassion condition, participants will be asked to indicate how bad they feel about their chosen situation before and after the induction, the manipulation was successful if they feel better or at least the same about their situation, but not worse. 

In the other-compassion condition, participants will be asked to indicate how compassionate they feel for their specific person. The manipulation was successful if they feel the same or better about that person. 

Lastly, at the end of the study all participants will be asked to write down what they think the study was about and how they felt while participating. The manipulation was successful if the participants weren’t able to guess the true aim of the study.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a: The IV is the Group which has 2 levels: self-compassion condition and other-compassion condition. It is a between group design. Participants will be assigned randomly to their condition; it will be counterbalanced by gender and student vs. general population.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b: The dependent variables are the change scores (pre – post induction) of the state self-compassion scale, the state general other-compassion scale, the state specific other-compassion scale, and the affect scale.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b: There will be six covariates: the narcissistic personality inventory score, the regulatory focus questionnaire score, the hypersensitive narcissism scale score, the Levenson self-report psychopathy score, the trait self-compassion scale score, and the trait compassion scale score.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Participants will be recruited at XXX University and online and will be invited to individual 1 ½ hour time-slots. Before the participants’ arrival, the present researcher will assess the stratification lists to determine which condition the participants would be in. Four lists will be used to stratify and ensure an even distribution of male/student, male/general-population, female/student, and female/general population in each induction condition. 
Upon arrival, participants will be briefed and give written consent. Next, participants will be presented with a laptop with the first block of questionnaires. This includes the demographical data and the trait measures. After, participants will be introduced by the researcher to the induction task, depending on the condition the participants were placed in, the instruction will either follow the SCMI or the OCMI. At this point, the participants will choose their specific situation. Following, participants will continue to fill out the manipulation check and the pre-induction state measures. After, participants will follow the induction by writing about 1. Mindfulness; 2. Common humanity; and 3. (Self-)kindness as specified through written instructions on the laptop. Once the participants finish writing, they will be asked to read what they have written carefully before answering the attention check. Next, the manipulation check item will be shown again, followed by the post-induction state measures. Once the participants finish the measures, they will be asked to write about what they think the study was about and how they felt during participation. Lastly, they will be debriefed and thanked for their participation. Participants will receive a compensation of either University participation credits or a voucher worth €12.50. 



Order Other-Compassion Condition: 
1.	Demographics: age, sex, nationality, education, marital status, employment, and medication. 
Trait measures:
2.	Trait Self-Compassion: Trait self-compassion was measured using the 12-item short form Self-Compassion Scale (SCS-SF; Raes et al., 2011). Items are rated on a 5-point Likert-scale. The scale includes three positive (self-kindness, common humanity, and mindfulness) and three negative components (self-judgement, isolation, and over-identification) of self-compassion.
3.	Trait Other-Compassion: The 16-item Compassion Scale (Pommier, Neff, & Toth-Kiraly, 2019) was used to measure trait other-compassion. Each item is rated on a 5 point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (almost never) to 5 (almost always). The scale includes three positive (kindness, common humanity, and mindfulness) and three negative components (indifference, separation, and disengagement) of compassion with factor loadings of .50 or higher.
4.	Regulatory Focus: Chronic regulatory focus will be measured by the 11-item Regulatory Focus Questionnaire (RFQ; Higgins et al., 2001), which aims to assess participants’ subjective prevention/promotion successes and failures. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (never/certainly false) to 5 (very often/certainly true). 
5.	Grandiose Narcissism: The 37-item Narcissistic Personality Inventory (NPI; Raskin & Hall, 1979; Morf & Rhodewalt, 1993) measures grandiose narcissistic traits. The NPI approaches narcissism dimensionally and only includes factor loadings greater than .35 (Emmons, 1987; Brown & Zeigler-Hill, 2004). Its items are scored on a 7-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (strongly agree) to 7 (strongly disagree). It has a four-factor loading solution: Leadership – Authority, Self-Absorption – Self-Administration, Superiority – Arrogance, and Exploitiveness – Entitlement (Emmons, 1987). 
6.	Vulnerable Narcissism: The 10-item Hypersensitive Narcissism Scale (HSNS; Hendin & Cheek, 1997) measures vulnerable narcissistic traits. Items are rated on a 7-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). 
7.	Psychopathy: The 26-item Levenson Self-Report Psychopathy Scale (LSRP; Levenson, Kiehl, & Fitzpatrick, 1995) measures the dimensions of sub-clinical psychopathic traits. The scale has an optimal 2-factor structure (Lynam, Whiteside, & Jones, 1999; Douma et al., in press); one primary psychopathy subscale measuring selfish, uncaring, and manipulative content towards others, and one secondary psychopathy subscale assessing anti-social behavior, impulsivity, and a self-defeating lifestyle. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). 

Pre-Induction State measures:
8.	State Self-Compassion: To measure state self-compassion, the newly developed state Self-Compassion Scale (Neff, in press) will be used, in which participants are asked to think of a painful or difficult situation in their life while answering the items. The scale consists of 18 items which are scored on a 5 point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (not at all true for me) to 5 (very true for me). The measure includes 6 subscales: kindness, self-judgement, common humanity, isolation, mindfulness, and over-identification. 
9.	Affect: An adapted version of the Affect Valuation Index (AVI; Tsai & Knutson, 2006) will be used to measure changes in positive and negative affect. The original AVI asks responders to indicate their average ideal and actual affect over the past week, whereas this study asked to rate the current actual affect. 30-items were rated on a 5-point Scale ranging from 1 (never) to 5 (all the time). 
10.	State Other-Compassion (General): The General State Other-compassion scale was developed by the current authors by adapting the items on the Compassion Scale to match the language used in the state Self-Compassion Scale. The instructions of the questionnaire ask participants to indicate how they feel about people in general (everyoneone, strangers neighbours etc…) right now. The final version includes 16-items, which are scored on a 5-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very true for me). The items are grouped into six subscales, following the Compassion scale: kindness, common humanity, mindfulness, indifference, separation, and disengagement).
11.	Specific Person Check: Participants are asked to pick a specific person they think about during the induction. The are supposed to name the person, indicate their relationship, how important that person is to them and how much they like that person. 
12.	Manipulation Check: Before and after the induction a manipulation check will be inserted, in which participants indicate how compassionate they feel for their chosen person in the moment. Answers are scored on a 5-point Likert-Scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (a great deal). 
13.	State Other-Compassion (Specific): The State Specific Other-compassion scale was developed by the current authors by adapting the items on the Compassion Scale to match the language used in the state Self-Compassion Scale, while consulting with Neff who’s developed previous compassion scales with her team. The instructions of the questionnaire ask participants to think about a difficult or painful situation someone they know is experiencing and indicate how they feel about the specific person right now. The final version includes 16-items, which are scored on a 5-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very true for me). The items are grouped into six subscales, following the Compassion scale: kindness, common humanity, mindfulness, indifference, separation, and disengagement).
14.	Other-Compassion Induction: Participants will be asked to think of a particular situation that is painful or difficult to someone they know before the induction.
Other-compassion will be induced by administering an Other-Compassion Mindstate induction, which was developed by the current authors by adapting Neff et al.’s SCMI. The current authors have changed the wording to facilitate other-compassion by asking the participants to think of a particular situation that is painful or difficult to someone they know, while encouraging the participant to relate to the other person’s struggle. The induction follows the three positive components of compassion: mindfulness, common humanity, and kindness. Each component is facilitated by a component specific writing prompt, which asks participants to write at least 200 words of compassionate language to their chosen person. The writing task is followed by an attention check which asks participants to indicate what was asked of them during the writing ask, i.e. to write about someone’s feelings in an accepting and validating way, consider how going through difficult situations is part of being human, and write to the other person like a supportive friend. Apart from the correct above option, two more items are included in the attention check which do not fit describe the task accurately.
Post-Induction State measures:
15.	Manipulation Check (see above) 
16.	State Other-Compassion (Specific) (see above)
17.	State Other-Compassion (General) (see above)
18.	State Self-Compassion (see above)
19.	Affect (see above)
20.	 Overall manipulation check (what was the study about? How did you feel while participating?)


Order Self-Compassion Condition: 
1.	Demographics 
Trait measures:
2.	Trait Self-Compassion
3.	Trait Other-Compassion
4.	Regulatory Focus 
5.	Grandiose Narcissism 
6.	Vulnerable Narcissism 
7.	Psychopathy 

Pre-Induction State measures:
8.	State Other-Compassion (General)
9.	Specific Person Check
10.	State Other-Compassion (Specific)
11.	Affect 
12.	Manipulation Check: Before and after the induction a manipulation check will be inserted, in which participants indicate how bad they feel about their chosen situation in the moment. Answers are given on a 5-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 (extremely bad) to 5 (extremely good).
13.	State Self-Compassion 
14.	Self-Compassion Induction: Participants will be asked to think of a particular situation that is painful or difficult to them before the induction.
Self-compassion will be induced by administering the Self-Compassion Mindset Induction (SCMI; Neff et al., in preparation). The SCMI experimentally induces a self-compassionate mindset, in which participants are asked to think of one specific situation that is currently painful or difficult for them. The induction follows the three positive components of self-compassion: mindfulness, common humanity, and kindness. Each component has its own writing prompt which encourages participants to write at least 200 words addressed to themselves in a compassionate language. The writing task will be followed by an attention check in which participants indicate what was asked of them during the induction, i.e. to write about their feelings in an accepting and validating way, consider how going through difficult situations is part of being human, and write to themselves like a supportive friend. The intention check includes the above option, in addition to two other items, which do not accurately describe what was asked of them. 
Post-Induction State measures:
15.	Manipulation Check (see above)
16.	State Self-Compassion 
17.	Affect 
18.	State Other-Compassion (General) 
19.	State Other-Compassion (Specific) 
20.	Overall manipulation check
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: Group. state self-compassion change score (pre self-compassion - post self-compassion), state other-compassion general (pre - post), state other-compassion specific (pre-post), affect (pre-post).

To analyse the differences between the two condition groups (self-compassion induction vs. other-compassion induction) on the dependent variables a MANOVA will be conducted. The group variable will be the fixed factor, and the change in state self-compassion, state general other-compassion, state specific other-compassion,  and affect will be the dependent variables. (Hypothesis 1 + 7)
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi: Change scores in state self-compassion (pre-post), state general othger-compassion (pre-post), state specific other-compassion (pre-post), and affect (pre-post). Further, the total NPI score, total HSNS, and total LSRP. Subscale scores for NPI and LSRP may be used for more detailed analyses. (Hypothesis 3 + 4 + 6)

4 ANCOVAS with either change in state self-compassion, or state general other-compassion, or state specific other compassion, or affect as the dependent variable, group as the fixed factor, and NPI as a covariate 
4 ANCOVAS with either change in state self-compassion, or state general other-compassion, or state specific other compassion, or affect as the dependent variable, group as the fixed factor, and HSNS as a covariate 
4 ANCOVAS with either change in state self-compassion, or state general other-compassion, or state specific other compassion, or affect as the dependent variable, group as the fixed factor, and LSRP as a covariate

The NPI and HSNS are used as narcissism has had mixed findings in previous research. It can be assumed that is is negatively related to low other-compassion, through superiority and low concerns for others and to high self-compassion as it may relate to self-confidence and authority feelings typical in narcissism. 
The LSRP (psychopathy) is added as psychopathy does not seem to have been measured with compassion, but rather only with empathy, and findings have been mixed. Theoretically, it would be logical that psychopathy has an influence on compassion due to characteristics such as coldheartedness.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Other than good English or Dutch language abilities, there are no pre-selection rules.

Participants will be recruited through the University’s research participation system, flyer advertisement, and online/social media advertisement through e.g. Facebook. Data will be collected from participants who give written consent, are above 18 years of age, and have good Dutch or English language abilities. The participation will take place within the university buildings of XXX University.

Research which has previously measured self-compassion before and after a compassion induction (though a different induction technique was used, i.e. compassion focused therapy) has shown an effect size of d = .57 (Sommers-Spijkerman et al. (2018)) when assessing 120 participants (60 per group). This leads us to assume that we can also expect a medium effect size. 
Based on a g*power calculation for ANCOVA with an effect size of f = .25 (medium), power = .80, and alpha = .05 with 1 IV with 2 levels and 6 covariates, we require a sample size of at least n = 158 participants. Currently we are aiming to collect 200 participants, 100 per group.
Data collection will be terminated once the data of 200 participants has been collected.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-fourth.fourth.ques: Change scores in state self-compassion (pre-post), state general othger-compassion (pre-post), state specific other-compassion (pre-post), and affect (pre-post). Further, the trait self-compassion and trait other-compassion scores calculated as intended by the authors of the scale and possible sub scale calculation (positive and negative scales). (Hypothesis 5)

4 ANCOVAS with either change in state self-compassion, or state general other-compassion, or state specific other-compassion, or affect as the dependent variable, group as the fixed factor, and trait self-compassion as a covariate 
4 ANCOVAS with either change in state self-compassion, or state general other-compassion, or state specific other-compassion, or affect as the dependent variable, group as the fixed factor, and trait other-compassion as a covariate
Trait self-compassion and other-compassion are used to relate to the induction conditions.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques: Change scores in state self-compassion (pre-post), state general othger-compassion (pre-post), state specific other-compassion (pre-post), and affect (pre-post). Further, the regulatory focus score calculated as intended by the authors of the scale. (Hypothesis 2)

4 ANCOVAS with either change in state self-compassion, or state general other-compassion, or state specific other compassion, or affect as the dependent variable, group as the fixed factor, and regulatory focus as a covariate
Regulatory focus may play a role in compassion as higher avoidant focus can be assumed to lead to lower overall increase in compassion.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-further.further.qu: Post-hoc follow-up analyses will be used where needed.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
Cases will be excluded if the induction wasn’t completed or participants decide to withdraw prematurely. Cases may be excluded if the manipulation checks have been failed, i.e. not having understood the instruction of the induction. 
Data will be excluded on a data-based outlier criterion of values below or above 2 standard deviations.

attributes.title: Preference for Black vs. White Applicants in Hierarchy-Attenuating vs. Hierarchy-Enhancing Roles

name.value: Preference for Black vs. White Applicants in Hierarchy-Attenuating vs. Hierarchy-Enhancing Roles

other.value:
We will also test multiple potential moderator items, including Race-Status Associations, pro-White/anti-Black bias, Social Dominance Orientation, and perceived importance of fit between applicant and organization. Finally, we will probe as an exploratory DV participants’ overall impressions via an open-ended item.
Below is a sample of the RSA measure: 
Race- Status Associations—Occupational Status
For this activity, you will see a series of faces. You will be asked to guess the job/occupation of the person shown. You will only be allowed to choose one job per person. 
 
Please make your best guess.

 

What is this person’s job?
●	Doctor
●	Dishwasher
●	Engineer
●	Garbage collector
●	Scientist
●	Taxi Driver
●	Lawyer
●	Cashier
●	CEO
●	Maid
●	Prostitute
●	Nurse
●	Janitor
●	Professor

Social Dominance Orientation

Please read each of the following statements carefully.

Show how much you favor or oppose each idea below by selecting a number from 1 to 7 on the scale below. You can work quickly; your first feeling is generally best. 

1.	An ideal society requires some groups to be on top and others to be on the bottom.
2.	Some groups of people are simply inferior to other groups.
3.	No one group should dominate in society.
4.	Groups at the bottom are just as deserving as groups at the top.
5.	Group equality should not be our primary goal.
6.	It is unjust to try to make groups equal.
7.	We should do what we can to equalize conditions for different groups.
8.	We should work to give all groups an equal chance to succeed.
9.	When counting up, the number nine comes after the number ten. 
(Attention Check)

Importance of Fit Dimensions in Hiring Beliefs
1.	In hiring, it is important to consider how similar an applicant's beliefs/values would be to his/her coworkers. 
2.	In hiring, it is important to consider how similar in status an applicant would be to his/her coworkers.
3.	In hiring, it is important to consider how similar an applicant would be in race/ethnicity to his/her coworkers.
4.	In hiring, it is important to consider the environment the applicant enters, to protect them from prejudice
Committee Feedback
 
Finally, please imagine that you are meeting with the hiring committee and you have been asked to provide your impressions of this candidate to the committee. Please do so below, explaining why you believe the company should or should not hire this candidate. (3-5 sentences)
We predict that for our White participants, importance of racial similarity fit will interact with hierarchy-relevance of the role to predict applicant fit. Specifically, we predict that participants who highly endorse the belief that racial fit is important in hiring will prefer the White applicant in the hierarchy-enhancing versus hierarchy-attenuating role.

sample.value: The target sample size will be 1200 participants (150 per cell: high versus low-status role; hierarchy-attenuating versus enhancing organization), enough to guarantee greater than 99% power to detect an interactive effect size of R = .21 (the average effect size in social psychology historically; Richard, Bond, & Stokes-Zoota, 2003) after exclusions.

analyses.value: We will use three-way ANOVA models to test the main and interactive effects of applicant preferences in the high or low-status job in the hierarchy-attenuating or hierarchy-enhancing organization for the White or Black applicant.

outliers.value: We will recruit participants who have indicated that they are White, excluding participants who do not indicate that they are White in a final demographic portion of the survey. These exclusions will be made prior to data analysis.

dependent.value:
In a scenario adapted from Pedulla (2014), participants will be asked to imagine consulting for a friend, who works at a local organization currently seeking a hire, by “reviewing the resume of one of the job candidates.” We will manipulate role status by describing the open position as CEO (high status) or entry level associate (low status). We will manipulate hierarchy-relevance of the role by describing the organization as a nonprofit (hierarchy-attenuating) or a hedge fund (hierarchy-enhancing). Each participant will then review the resume of a White or Black job applicant. Participants will then be asked to thoroughly review the job applicant’s resume (approximately 60 seconds). The key dependent variable is applicant preferences, including perceptions of applicant fit and capability, and recommended compensation, including recommended starting salary and signing bonus.
 
Participants will indicate their applicant impressions by responding to the following questions (randomized). Previous work suggests two dimensions of applicant preferences—one reflecting applicant fit, another reflecting applicant capability.


1 (not at all likely) – 7 (extremely likely)
1.	How likely is it that you would recommend interviewing this applicant for the job?
2.	How likely is it that you would recommend hiring this applicant for the job?
3.	How likely is it that this applicant would be hired for the job?
4.	How likely is it that the applicant has the necessary skills for the job?
5.	If hired, how likely do you think it is that the applicant would feel comfortable in this position?

6.	How qualified do you think the applicant is?
7.	If hired, how well do you think that the applicant would fit in with his or her coworkers?
8.	If hired, how similar do you think the applicant would feel to his or her coworkers?

We will also test recommended compensation.

$100,000-$500,000 [$10,000-$90,000 for low-status role]
1.	What yearly salary would you recommend that this applicant receive?
$10,000-$50,000 [$100-$900 for low-status role]
1.	What starting bonus would you recommend that this applicant receive?

As an exploratory step we will include items related to perceived warmth. 

1. Did the applicant strike you as likeable?
2. Did the applicant seem trustworthy?

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of 8 conditions—A high or low-status job at a  hierarchy-attenuating job or hierarchy-enhancing organization evaluating a Black or White job applicant. Participants will be selected for the study if they are White, according to Prolific’s pre-screen questionnaire.

hypothesis.value: How does hierarchy-relevance of jobs impact Whites’ responses to Black and White job applicants? Prior work suggests that White evaluators rate White job applicants as a better fit for a hierarchy-enhancing role than a similarly high-status hierarchy-attenuating role. This study aims to replicate this effect and extend it by exploring the impact of job status. We predict an effect of hierarchy-relevance of job (hierarchy-enhancing, hierarchy-attenuating) in predicting White evaluators’ ratings of White and Black applicant fit, such that evaluators rate a White applicant as a better fit for a hierarchy-enhancing (versus -attenuating) role (Hypothesis 1) and a Black applicant as a better fit for a hierarchy-attenuating (versus -enhancing) role (Hypothesis 2). As an exploratory step, we will also test whether these effects are moderated by job status (high, low) by asking White participants to evaluate a White or Black applicant seeking either a high-status (i.e., CEO) or low status (i.e., entry level associate) role at a hierarchy-enhancing (hedge fund) or hierarchy-enhancing (nonprofit) organization.

registration_responses.dependent:
In a scenario adapted from Pedulla (2014), participants will be asked to imagine consulting for a friend, who works at a local organization currently seeking a hire, by “reviewing the resume of one of the job candidates.” We will manipulate role status by describing the open position as CEO (high status) or entry level associate (low status). We will manipulate hierarchy-relevance of the role by describing the organization as a nonprofit (hierarchy-attenuating) or a hedge fund (hierarchy-enhancing). Each participant will then review the resume of a White or Black job applicant. Participants will then be asked to thoroughly review the job applicant’s resume (approximately 60 seconds). The key dependent variable is applicant preferences, including perceptions of applicant fit and capability, and recommended compensation, including recommended starting salary and signing bonus.
 
Participants will indicate their applicant impressions by responding to the following questions (randomized). Previous work suggests two dimensions of applicant preferences—one reflecting applicant fit, another reflecting applicant capability.


1 (not at all likely) – 7 (extremely likely)
1.	How likely is it that you would recommend interviewing this applicant for the job?
2.	How likely is it that you would recommend hiring this applicant for the job?
3.	How likely is it that this applicant would be hired for the job?
4.	How likely is it that the applicant has the necessary skills for the job?
5.	If hired, how likely do you think it is that the applicant would feel comfortable in this position?

6.	How qualified do you think the applicant is?
7.	If hired, how well do you think that the applicant would fit in with his or her coworkers?
8.	If hired, how similar do you think the applicant would feel to his or her coworkers?

We will also test recommended compensation.

$100,000-$500,000 [$10,000-$90,000 for low-status role]
1.	What yearly salary would you recommend that this applicant receive?
$10,000-$50,000 [$100-$900 for low-status role]
1.	What starting bonus would you recommend that this applicant receive?

As an exploratory step we will include items related to perceived warmth. 

1. Did the applicant strike you as likeable?
2. Did the applicant seem trustworthy?
registration_responses.conditions: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of 8 conditions—A high or low-status job at a  hierarchy-attenuating job or hierarchy-enhancing organization evaluating a Black or White job applicant. Participants will be selected for the study if they are White, according to Prolific’s pre-screen questionnaire.
registration_responses.hypothesis: How does hierarchy-relevance of jobs impact Whites’ responses to Black and White job applicants? Prior work suggests that White evaluators rate White job applicants as a better fit for a hierarchy-enhancing role than a similarly high-status hierarchy-attenuating role. This study aims to replicate this effect and extend it by exploring the impact of job status. We predict an effect of hierarchy-relevance of job (hierarchy-enhancing, hierarchy-attenuating) in predicting White evaluators’ ratings of White and Black applicant fit, such that evaluators rate a White applicant as a better fit for a hierarchy-enhancing (versus -attenuating) role (Hypothesis 1) and a Black applicant as a better fit for a hierarchy-attenuating (versus -enhancing) role (Hypothesis 2). As an exploratory step, we will also test whether these effects are moderated by job status (high, low) by asking White participants to evaluate a White or Black applicant seeking either a high-status (i.e., CEO) or low status (i.e., entry level associate) role at a hierarchy-enhancing (hedge fund) or hierarchy-enhancing (nonprofit) organization.

attributes.title: Stereotype Congruence and the Process of Person Perception, Replication

summary.value:
We are preregistering a replication of a study that investigates how stereotype knowledge
about specific groups (e.g., the extent to which a person thinks that Black men are stereotyped as dominant) influences the cognitive process of person perception (e.g., perceiving a Black male target as dominant).

In this study, participants will categorize faces (Race: Asian, Black White; Gender: Female, Male) as either "Less" or "More" of one of six traits (Attractive, Dominant, Friendly, Intelligent, Strong, Trustworthy). The manipulation of faces is within-subject; the manipulation of trait is between-subject. This categorization will be performed using MouseTracker; our outcome variables measure deviation in trajectory (Area Under Curve, or AUC) and spatial complexity (Entropy). After completing this task, participants will report their stereotype knowledge for all six race-by-gender groups on all six traits (e.g., "To what extent are Black men stereotyped as dominant?"). 

We predict that people, as stereotype knowledge increases for a given target-trait combination (e.g., Black males being stereotyped as dominance; referred to as "stereotype congruence"), participants will show less deviation in trajectories (i.e., lower AUC) and simpler trajectories (i.e., lower Entropy) when categorizing faces as "more" of the relevant trait. Conversely, they will show more deviation in trajectories and more complex trajectories when categorizing faces as "less" of the relevant trait. 

We will test the robustness of our results by specifying three models with alternate specifications of random effects. We will explore whether specific traits and race-by-gender effects emerge after stereotype congruence is accounted for. Finally, we will test how much variance is shared between AUC and Entropy and whether the effects for each are maintained removing after removing their shared variance from the model. 

In our exploratory study, we analyzed the data of 220 people. We will collect 150 participants' responses for analysis in this replication. For our analyses, we will use the uploaded code.
